info.name: BHT EMR API
info.description:
The BHT EMR API is a [RESTful](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_state_transfer) API providing an abstraction layer to a customised [OpenMRS 1.7](https://openmrs.org/) database and application engine for EMRs ... FIXME. ## Authentication The API makes use of API keys for authentication. Almost all requests to the API must be accompanied by an API key. API keys are generated by logging into the API [see Logging in]. Keys are valid for 24 hours and a user can only have one valid key at a given point in time. Generating a new key invalidates any existing key. ## Request/Response Structure The API primarily consumes and spits out JSON. It makes use of a number of HTTP verbs for manipulating and access resources. All POST and PUT requests must be accompanied by a JSON payload and a `Content-type=application/json` header. Below is a summary of the verbs the API recognises.
Verb Interpretation Expected Response Status
GET Retrieve some resource.
eg. GET /api/v1/patients to retrieve patients 		200 - Ok
POST Create a resource. 201 - Created
PUT Update a resource. 200 - Ok
DELETE Destroy some resource. 204 - No Content
Successful requests get a response with a status code of either 200, 201, or 204. For 200 and 201 responses a response body is always available. The body is the object (or list of objects) that was being accessed. Failed requests are flagged by 4XX status codes. Errors in this range generally have a response body of the following structure: ```json { "errors": [ "Error message", "Another error message", ..., "More error messages" ] } ``` However a 400 error for POST and PUT requests come as: ```json { "errors": { "field": "This field is required" ... "some_other_field": "This field too is required" } } ``` ### Response status codes Below is a description the response codes the API returns:
Status Code Status Text Description
200 Ok Request was successful
201 Created Resource has been created
204 No Content Resource has been deleted
400 Bad Request Received a malformed request from client
401 Unauthorized A valid API key is required
403 Forbidden Logged in user is not allowed to perform request
500 Internal Server Error API is ill, only thing that can be done is contacting the system administrator
## Pagination All endpoints (except a few) that return a list of values are paginated. Pagination by default limits results to 10 items. A number of parameters are provided that control the pagination. Following is a table describing them:
Parameter Description
page Specifies the page to retrieve (defaults to 0). Pages start from 0.
page_size Specifies number of results per page (defaults to 10).
paginate Switches off pagination. Only `false` is accepted as a value, anything else is ignored.
### Pagination examples ```bash # Retrieve page 5 of 20 items per page curl 'http://localhost/api/v1/observations?page=5&page_size=20' // Retrieve all items without paginating curl 'http://localhost/api/v1/observations?pagination=false' ```

item.description:
This section contains endpoints for searching various entities in the database.
These routes are meant to compliment the rudimentary search available for the
various high level entities (eg /observations?encounter_id=query).

request.description: ART regimens can be retrieved by either specifying a patient_id or manually specifying a weight. When a patient_id is specified the service automatically fetches the patient weight and tb status of the patient to use in coming up with valid regimens for the patient. In the case of retrieving by weight there is a second optional parameter available `tb_regimen` which indicates that the regimens must be adapted for TB patients. `tb_regimen` can either be 'true' or 'false' (defaults to false). Refer to the examples for more details.

request.description:
Logging in is a way of generating an API key which must be used in subsequent requests to the API that require authorisation. The generated api key is valid for 24 hours.

NOTE: Clients are limited to one API key at a time. A log in replaces any existing api key.

request.description:
# /api/v1/people

This endpoint returns a list of people registered as either patients or users. By default only 10 random people are returned. Pagination is supported through the use of the parameters page and page_size as follows:

	http://<host>:<port>/api/v1/people?page=0&page_size
	
The example above retrieve the first 50 people.
GET localhost:3000/api/v1/people/18904/names

User creation requires an existing person to be associated with the new user. Thus it is mandatory that a `person_id` be specified in the request body.

See: (Retrieving user roles)[#Retrieving-user-roles] for valid roles.

response.name: Creating users

Creating encounters requires 2 parameters namely `encounter_type_id` and `patient_id`. A third optional parameter `provider_id` may be specified. This however defaults to the current user.

NOTE: Encounters currently aren't linked to orders but will soon be thus expect an additional optional `order_id` to be included soon.

request.description: Create drug orders in bulk. This end point allows creation of multiple drug orders on a 'TREATMENT' encounter in one swoop. See the request structure and response body below for more details.

header.value: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE, OPTIONS, HEAD
header.name: access-control-allow-methods

request.description: http://127.0.0.1:3000/api/v1/drugs?name=F

This is a bulk API endpoint that enables dispensing multiple drugs in one. Drugs are dispensed on previously created drug orders only. Every dispensation requires a drug order and the quantity to dispense.

header.name: Cache-Control
header.description: Tells all caching mechanisms from server to client whether they may cache this object. It is measured in seconds

header.name: Content-Type
header.description: The mime type of this content

header.name: ETag
header.description: An identifier for a specific version of a resource, often a message digest

header.name: Transfer-Encoding
header.description: The form of encoding used to safely transfer the entity to the user. Currently defined methods are: chunked, compress, deflate, gzip, identity.

header.name: Vary
header.description: Tells downstream proxies how to match future request headers to decide whether the cached response can be used rather than requesting a fresh one from the origin server.

header.name: X-Request-Id
header.description: Custom header

header.name: X-Runtime
header.description: Custom header

request.description:
This endpoint provides access to all appointments ever created. Appointments are basically just Observations having a concept of 'Appointment'. They are returned in descending order of obs_datetime.

### Available filters

- obs_datetime: Limit results to appointments that fall on this date
- person_id: Limit results to appointments belonging to this person
- location_id: Limit results to appointments made at this location
- encounter_id: Limit results to appointments belonging to this encounter (NOTE: there is no validation of whether the encounter is an appointment encounter)

header.name: Cache-Control
header.description: Tells all caching mechanisms from server to client whether they may cache this object. It is measured in seconds

header.name: Content-Type
header.description: The mime type of this content

header.name: ETag
header.description: An identifier for a specific version of a resource, often a message digest

header.name: Transfer-Encoding
header.description: The form of encoding used to safely transfer the entity to the user. Currently defined methods are: chunked, compress, deflate, gzip, identity.

header.name: Vary
header.description: Tells downstream proxies how to match future request headers to decide whether the cached response can be used rather than requesting a fresh one from the origin server.

header.name: X-Request-Id
header.description: Custom header

header.name: X-Runtime
header.description: Custom header

request.description: This endpoint provides access to all relationship types in store. Filtering is supported through the `search_string` parameters. For example to retrieve all relationships containing the term 'doctor' use `<address>/api/v1/types/relationships?search_string=doctor`.

header.name: Cache-Control
header.description: Tells all caching mechanisms from server to client whether they may cache this object. It is measured in seconds

header.name: Content-Type
header.description: The mime type of this content

header.name: ETag
header.description: An identifier for a specific version of a resource, often a message digest

header.name: Transfer-Encoding
header.description: The form of encoding used to safely transfer the entity to the user. Currently defined methods are: chunked, compress, deflate, gzip, identity.

header.name: Vary
header.description: Tells downstream proxies how to match future request headers to decide whether the cached response can be used rather than requesting a fresh one from the origin server.

header.name: X-Request-Id
header.description: Custom header

header.name: X-Runtime
header.description: Custom header
